The manuscript was written through contributions of all authors. Graphical abstract Propylene is an important chemical feedstock that is largely produced via cracking of oil-derived naphtha. Direct conversion of propane into propylene may be a more attractive alternative. Specifically, propane dehydrogenation (DH) and oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) are promising for this transformation, albeit only DH has been industrially implemented. However, even the best DH catalysts (Pt-based) still suffer from deactivation. VOx- and BOx-based ODH catalysts result in significant over-oxidation and lack a mechanistic understanding. A common challenge in developing these catalysts is the broad distribution of surface species caused by the use of non-ordered catalyst supports. This hampers clear structure-performance correlations. Recent progress in the preparation of well-defined active sites on ordered supports has brought about improved catalysts, as well as fundamental insight into the working mechanism. This review will highlight recent advancements in the development of these catalysts and provide direction on the use of ordered supports for propane upgrading. Keywords Dehydrogenation Heterogeneous catalysis Porous materials Propane Zeolite 1 Introduction Propylene is one of the most important chemical feedstocks in the chemical industry, with approximately 8 billion metric tons produced annually [1,2]. It is used to produce a wide range of important chemicals, such as polypropylene (∼45 % of propylene production) and propylene oxide (∼10 % of propylene) [3]. These derived materials find applications in a variety of industries, such as textile, automotive, packaging, and construction [4]. Although propylene is a highly desired chemical, it is largely produced by steam and fluid cracking of naphtha, as a secondary product to ethylene [5]. However, the recent feedstock shift to the newly abundant, ethane-rich shale gas results in lower propylene yields in these processes (Fig. 1 a), and this shift results in a growing gap between propylene supply and demand (Fig. 1b). To narrow the gap and capitalize on the economic opportunity, on-purpose production of propylene from propane is of growing industrial interest. The two routes being heavily investigated for converting propane to propylene are propane non-oxidative dehydrogenation (DH) and oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH). The non-oxidative dehydrogenation of propane is gaining industrial importance (reaction 1) [5,6]. Advantages of DH include the high selectivity to propylene and the production of H2, a valuable side-product [5,6]. Further, DH industrial units have been optimized to feed directly into downstream units to produce polymers and other higher value chemicals, streamlining the value-chain [7]. In the past few years, many new DH units, with a capacity to produce up to 600,000 tons of propylene per year, have been built around the world [8,9]. This steady increase in industrial propane DH capacity allows companies to capitalize on propylene-propane price differential, and that growth is maintained by downstream gains in the propylene market. C3H8 ⇌ C3H6 + H2 (ΔH o 298K =124.6 kJ/mol) (reaction 1) Unfortunately, DH is significantly endothermic (reaction 1), making it an energetically costly process as the reaction requires temperatures of 600−650 °C [5]. In addition, DH catalysts suffer from severe deactivation due to coke formation (carbon deposits). The deactivation can be reversed by burning off the carbon (rejuvenation), however, the process is a disruptive regeneration step that must be consistently repeated in a semi-continuous manner to recover the catalyst activity [6,10]. Notwithstanding the drawbacks, DH is gaining importance in industry. The leading industrial processes use one of two catalysts (1) Pt-Sn catalysts for the Oleflex (UOP) and Steam Active Reforming (Uhde STAR) methods and (2) CrOx catalysts for the Catofin (CB&I Lummus) and Fluidized Bed Dehydrogenation (FBD) processes (Yarsintez-Snamprogetti) [11–14]. Both catalysts provide high olefin selectivity >80 % and are used in C3 and C4 upgrading [15]. These processes are optimized such that (i) cheap propane separated from shale gas can be used, (ii) the process can run continuously for 1–3 years as a result of the incorporated regeneration, and (iii) it can run at low pressure (Catofin) to increase the thermodynamic conversion [5]. However, Pt and CrOx catalysts have limited lifetimes, and this necessitates complete replacement due to the decreasing conversion with increasing total time-on-stream [11,13]. Along with new catalysts, new technologies are also continuously being developed to make DH more energy and cost effective. Notably, a new DH process, by Dow, has recently been developed to reduce the energy and capital costs. The fluidized catalytic dehydrogenation process (FCDh process) requires only one regenerator and reactor system without furnaces. Additionally, the FCDh process uses a Ga catalyst promoted with a trace amount of Pt, which can reduce the cost of making the catalyst [16]. An alternative propane conversion reaction that is of interest is ODH (reaction 2). By co-feeding oxygen, the reaction becomes exothermic, reducing the energy cost and circumventing catalyst deactivation by preventing coke buildup [5,17]. ODH is typically run and studied at a lower temperature (<550 °C) to avoid contribution from unselective gas phase chemistry, while DH is often run at higher to obtain high conversion of propane [5,18,19]. C3H8 + 0.5 O2 → C3H6 + H2O (ΔH o 298K = −117 kJ/mol) (reaction 2) However, because oxygen is more reactive towards propylene than propane, the overoxidation of the desired product is a significant challenge in ODH [5,17]. Due to this disadvantage, ODH is not yet applied industrially, but promising supported metal oxide catalysts are being investigated. For both DH and ODH, the main challenge lies in designing a low-cost, stable, and efficient catalyst. Achieving this goal requires the development of a material that can maintain structural integrity at reaction temperatures, can selectively convert propane to propylene, and can be repeatedly regenerated (important for DH). Current research efforts focus on the use of supported metals or metal oxides as the catalyst because of their ability to activate propane and undergo redox reactions [5,6,10,17]. The metal and metal oxide catalytic performance is dependent on the metal particle size, structure, location, choice of support, and extent of redox ability [5,6,10,17]. Many comprehensive reviews exist that focus on recent developments and challenges in the area pertaining to active sites and the relationship between structure and catalytic activity [5,6,10,17]. Here, we supplement the existing literature, explore the recent studies on supported DH and ODH catalysts, and discuss these findings based on support structure: ordered and nonordered supports. The support is an important aspect of a propane conversion catalyst because it can (i) stabilize the active sites by metal-support interaction, (ii) determine the dispersion and size of the active species, and (iii) alter the activity or/and selectivity of the metal oxide by changing the interaction between active sites and reactants (through modification of the electronic and geometric properties of active sites) [5,6,10,17]. As a result, there is an ongoing search for an optimal support for ODH and DH catalyst. Depending on the research purpose, either category of support can be used to answer fundamental questions or optimize catalytic performance. However, the fabrication process for ordered supports is more complicated as compared to nonordered supports, therefore it is necessary to evaluate the advantages and (cost) disadvantages of using ordered supports and materials in propylene production. The main aims of this review are to identify opportunities for using these ordered materials to overcome drawbacks in producing propylene and to provide a perspective on future directions in developing ordered materials. In short, this review focuses on (i) developments in ordered catalysts, (ii) methods to synthesize ordered materials, (iii) connection between catalyst structure and activity, (iv) differences in catalytic performance and stability between ordered and non-ordered materials, and (v) our view and suggestion on how to further improve current systems. 2 Support materials Many kinds of supports have been explored for ODH and DH catalysis. As stated above, the support serves to stabilize active sites and allow site dispersion which can alter the catalytic properties of the system. These supports can be categorized by ordered and non-ordered structures as defined below. 2.1 Nonordered supports Nonordered supports can be easily synthesized and play an important role in heterogeneous catalysis. In the context of this review, nonordered supports are materials that do not possess medium- and long-range order. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) isotherms of these materials are type II, which indicates either a lack of pores or the presence of only macropores in the materials [20]. The most prevalent non-ordered supports are silica (SiO2) and alumina (Al2O3). SiO2 is chemically inert, easy to synthesize and commercially available, making it a desirable catalyst support. However, due to the heterogeneity of the surface of nonordered supports, the structures of active sites will vary (i.e. isolated sites, polymeric sites, agglomerated nanoparticles) [21]. To combat this inconsistency, recent studies have taken advantages of the low density of silanols (Si−OH) on SiO2 dehydroxylated at 700 °C under vacuum (0.7 OH nm−2) to synthesize uniformly structured active sites using surface organometallic chemistry (SOMC) [21]. In SOMC, grafting organometallic complexes onto these dispersed and isolated Si−OH allows for the coordination sphere of the grafted metal to be controlled with great precision [22]. SOMC makes synthesis of identical sites possible and enables direct correlation between structure and catalytic activity. Along with SiO2, Al2O3 is another key support used in catalysis because of its high surface area, acid/base characteristics, and multiple phases [23]. Unlike SiO2, Al2O3 goes through different phase transitions [γ -> (γ- θ) -> (θ + α) -> α] when heated between 773 and 1573 K [24]. Each phase possesses different amounts of acid sites, which can affect the selectivity, catalytic activity, and structure of active sites [25]. Depending on the intended purpose of the support, either chemically inert SiO2 or catalytically active Al2O3 can be used. 2.2 Ordered supports In the context of this review, the term “ordered support” refers to a class of materials with well-defined structures (not necessarily crystalline) and large surface area. The BET isotherms of these materials indicate that the porous system contains one of or both micro- and mesopores (IUPAC type I or IV, respectively) [20,26]. One example of an ordered material is hierarchical mesoporous silica [27]. These types of structures have high surface areas (100 to ca. 1000 m2 g−1) and a pore network, making them attractive for heterogeneous catalysis [21,26,27]. The pore networks can be varied (e.g. SBA-15, SBA-16, MCM-41, and MCM-48) by modifying the synthesis method and the choice of surfactants [26]. The ability to alter the pore network is likely crucial for propane catalysis because it allows for flexibility in designing and stabilizing active sites [26,27]. This phenomenon has been observed in the dry reforming of methane (DRM), SBA-15 (a 2D hexagonal array of thick-walled (3−6 nm) cylindrical channels (5−10 nm) and high surface area (600-1000 m2 g−1)) has been studied as a support [27–29]. It was found that this structure prevented the sintering of Ni nanoparticles, which was a significant issue with amorphous supports (e.g. Al2O3). As a result, the catalyst was more stable and prevented the formation of catalyst-deactivating carbon filaments during DRM. Along with hierarchical mesoporous silica, zeolites are often explored as supports for propane conversion reactions. Zeolites are crystalline three-dimensional aluminosilicate materials made up of TO4 tetrahedra where T is Al or Si (referred to as T-sites) [30,31]. These T-sites ([SiO4]4− or [AlO4]5-) are linked together creating a microporous framework [30]. The most prevalent zeolite synthesis method is hydrothermal synthesis, a method that ages a gel precursor at elevated temperature and pressure [31]. By modifying the gel composition and the treatment conditions of the synthesis procedure, over 200 types of zeolites with various silicon-aluminum (Si/Al) ratios and pore structures have been discovered [32]. Additionally, active metal atoms can be inserted into zeolite structures by either direct synthesis (addition of a metal precursor solution to the hydrothermal gel mixture) or post-synthesis modification (i.e. incipient wetness impregnation, chemical vapor deposition, ion exchange, etc.). Incorporating active metal centers into a zeolite framework can make the zeolite more catalytically active. Additionally, the catalytic centers inside zeolites can behave differently from those supported on amorphous materials due to the confinement effect imposed by the zeolite structure [33–36]. By using different encapsulation strategies, the catalytic performance and stability of the active metals can be tailored. 3 Catalyst synthesis methods This review highlights the effect of supports and consequently their respective synthesis techniques on the performance of DH and ODH catalysts. Therefore, we provide a brief summary of the relevant synthesis techniques and the advantages and disadvantages associated with each method (Table 1 ) to lay the groundwork for our discussion. Synthesis procedures contain multiple variables (viz. temperature, precursor ratio, duration, etc.) and can result in catalysts with a wide variety of textural and reactive properties. For example, to exclusively create metal active sites inside the framework of a zeolite, hydrothermal (direct) synthesis is often used instead of impregnation. Since the precipitation of metal precursors and the zeolite crystallization happen simultaneously in hydrothermal synthesis, the metal active sites can be incorporated within the zeolite framework. On the other hand, impregnation is a simpler procedure, which consequently disperses metal active sites indiscriminately on the zeolite support, leading to the creation of various extra-framework sites. For a more detailed review of the different synthesis approaches, we invite readers to read these detailed reviews [22,37]. 4 Non-oxidative dehydrogenation of propane Recent research in propane DH has been focused on improving the very selective Pt and CrOx industrial catalysts [15]. The main drawbacks of these catalysts include coking and sintering-induced deactivation [5,6]. Therefore, a primary focus in the development of more robust catalysts is the support material which can provide a framework that inhibits carbon deposition and metal agglomeration. 4.1 Platinum Pt-containing catalysts are used commercially for propane dehydrogenation in the Honeywell United Oil Products (UOP) Oleflex, Uhde STAR, and Dow FCDh processes [13,14]. The Oleflex process uses a Sn-modified Pt material supported on γ-Al2O3, where 86 % selectivity is achieved for a single-pass conversion of 40 %, and the continuous catalyst regeneration cycle (CCR) lasts 5–8 days [15]. Pt is used for propane DH because of its ability to abstract the hydrogen atom and its low activity towards CC bonds [38]. While Pt catalysts are currently the most studied noble-metal for propane DH, there are several drawbacks to this material [15]. Most importantly, Pt is a rare metal and it suffers from long term deactivation [5,6]. Supported Pt catalysts, without the use of any additives (in particular Sn), are subject to deactivation from coke formation and metal particle sintering [39,40]. Coke formation will induce rapid deactivation because the carbon deposits will coat the metal active sites, however, it can be reversed by thermal regeneration under oxidative conditions [41]. Sintering, on the other hand, creates aggregated Pt particles which not only lower the activity but also facilitate unwanted side-reactions such as cracking and hydrogenolysis [42]. Sintering induces poor reaction selectivity and will cause gradual, long-term loss of activity. Ultimately, this deactivation will necessitate complete catalyst replacement [41]. To prolong the life of Pt catalysts, industrial processes, like Oleflex, use an oxygen-chlorine treatment to partially redisperse agglomerated Pt during CCR [43]. Although some reactivity can be recovered through re-dispersion, the catalyst still has to be replaced every few years due to gradual deactivation [41,43]. Industrial processes always have pitfalls (e.g., catalyst life, complex regeneration treatments), which provide the need for further research and development into higher performing and more stable catalysts. In this search for improved propane DH catalysts, the scientific community has explored the role of support materials in the formation and long-term stability of active sites. The support can directly impact the structure of metal active species thus influencing the reaction product outcome. Since Pt is a highly productive catalyst for propane DH, much research has gone into optimizing a support for this metal. There are three requirements for a higher performing Pt catalyst: (1) a support that can disperse the metal to prevent sintering at prolonged high temperatures (600−700 °C); (2) the active component must be stabilized under operating conditions to maintain high selectivity, and (3) a low concentration of strong acid sites must be attained to prevent coking [15]. 4.1.1 Non-ordered support Non-ordered supports are desirable for Pt-catalyzed DH due to their low cost, stability, and facile customization. γ-Al2O3 is the most commonly used support, because of its high surface area and robust chemical, thermal properties and low price. However, γ-Al2O3 is highly acidic which leads to unwanted coke formation and alkane isomerization. Recent efforts to reduce coking, increase dispersion, and minimize sintering, involve the use of dopants (Na, Zn, Co, Sn, Mg, B, V, Nb, Ti, In, Mn, Cu, Ga, Ge) to poison strong acid sites on the support and stabilize Pt nanoparticles. [44–57] In general, the dopants were found to increase propane conversion, propylene selectivity, and catalyst stability (Table 2 ). Of the dopants described in Table 2, Sn and K are widely studied due to their use in industry (Oleflex). [13,15] Both promoters increase propylene selectivity by minimizing sintering. Additionally, they both reduce coke formation at the active Pt centers, each through a different mechanism [58–60]. For Sn, there is still debate in the literature about its mechanism, but it is believed to modify the electronic and geometric properties of Pt sites through increasing the electron density of Pt atoms. This interplay between Pt and Sn can weaken the interaction with coke precursors (partially dehydrogenated hydrocarbons). Weaker attraction between carbon species and Pt atoms leads to the diffusion of coke to the support, preventing Pt active site deactivation from coke buildup [61–63]. Furthermore, it has been suggested that Sn forms an alloy with Pt which stabilizes small Pt ensembles (Pt3Sn, the optimum calculated structure for propane DH in term of geometric and electronic effects) and partially covers the more reactive surfaces of Pt. [64,65] By blocking the surfaces that are responsible for the CC bond scission or hydrogenolysis reaction, the selectivity for propylene is increased. [64,65] Additionally, stable and isolated Sn2+ sites are active for propane DH, which could potentially contribute to the observed catalytic activity of Pt-Sn catalysts. [63,66] Another prominent promoter for Pt/Al2O3 catalysts is Zn, which functions similarly to a Sn dopant. [67] Zn changes the electronic and geometric properties of Pt active sites. Zn can form a Pt1Zn1 alloy with Pt, which will suppress structure-sensitive side reactions such as cracking and hydrogenolysis. [67]. Additionally, Zn can lower the energy of the filled electronic states in Pt and weaken the interaction between Pt 5d orbitals and reactive adsorbates, which decreases coking [65]. At low loading (<0.5 % weight) K also increases the coke resistance of PtSn/γ-Al2O3 by blocking the acid sites of Al2O3, thus inhibiting the formation of long carbon chains. [23] Further, K could also aid in the stabilization of small Pt clusters making the catalyst more active [33]. Overall, these promoters improve propane DH catalysts by increasing active metal site dispersion and reducing coke formation. In addition to alumina, silica is a well-researched support for Pt propane DH catalysts. Silica has milder acidity than alumina, which minimizes cracking reactions, potentially making silica a more coke-resistant DH support. However, Pt interacts less strongly with silica as compared to alumina, causing the Pt species to be less stable. The weaker metal-support interaction results in more severe Pt sintering and a less stable catalyst for propane DH. [68] To prevent sintering and test the coke resistance of silica supports, Sn was used to promote the dispersion of Pt atoms through the same active Pt-Sn alloy observed on Al2O3 [68–70]. When directly compared, PtSn/SiO2 was found to be ∼10x less active than PtSn/Al2O3 [69]. This lower activity was attributed to the low stability and low density of the active Pt-Sn moieties [68,70]. Further, the synthesis technique was found to significantly impact the dopant’s effectiveness. For example, Stagg et al. showed that co-impregnation synthesized PtSn/SiO2 led to more alloyed Pt-Sn, while sequential impregnations of Pt and Sn resulted in unalloyed, sintering-prone Pt species. [68] Even when the co-impregnation synthesis method was used to minimize unalloyed Pt, the catalyst did not maintain dispersed Pt sites after thermal regeneration. Therefore, despite the presence of promoters, sintering persisted and resulted in rapid catalyst deactivation overshadowing any expected benefits form the milder support acidity [68]. 4.1.2 Ordered support Small Pt clusters have been shown to be more active and selective than large Pt nanoparticles for propane DH [71–73]. For example, the turnover frequency (TOF) of a 1 nm Pt cluster (TOFpropane = 1.28 s−1) is almost three times that of a 9 nm Pt cluster (TOFpropane = 0.45 s−1). [71] Further, DFT calculations showed that small particles with mainly exposed Pt(211) can activate propane with a lower energy barrier than Pt(111) facets on large particles [71,74]. However, the controlled synthesis of small metal clusters was unattainable until recently. A promising method to achieve few-atom Pt particles is using zeolitic supports. Zeolites have high crystallinity, tunable acid sites, high thermal stability, and, most importantly, the ability to isolate Pt clusters [33–36,75–79]. The highly ordered frameworks of zeolites can encapsulate small Pt clusters and impose a high migration barrier on Pt atoms, allowing for longer time on stream (TOS) catalyst stability [80]. Recently, research efforts have focused on the generation of active sites within the zeolite crystal because the framework species are more stable than extra framework species (i.e. active sites that are anchored on the outside of the zeolite rather than a part of the structure) [33–36,75]. The MFI structure is commonly used for Pt catalysts because it contains narrow channels that can confine nanometric active sites [35,81,82]. The MFI pore system can be categorized into three areas: straight channels (diameter ca. 0.5 nm), sinusoidal channels (diameter ca. 0.5 nm), and intersectional voids (diameter ca. 0.9 nm) [83–85]. A common way to incorporate active species into a zeolite framework is through hydrothermal synthesis. However, hydrothermal synthesis of Pt-alloy clusters often leads to 1) extra-framework active Pt sites instead of confined nanoclusters because zeolite crystallization takes longer than Pt precipitation, and 2) unselective deposition of active sites inside both the channels and intersectional voids (preferentially placing Pt clusters in the channels instead of intersectional voids could lead to active sites of less than 0.5 nm) [86,87]. To overcome these challenges, various synthesis methods have been developed to encapsulate Pt clusters inside the MFI structure. For example, Okubo and coworkers developed a procedure that enhanced the rate of crystallization for the ZSM-5 zeolite to match with the formation of metal nanoclusters [34]. This was achieved by heating a mixture of aged aluminosilicate precursor and metal precursor in a tubular reactor. Through this synthesis, Pt nanoparticles were successfully encapsulated and well dispersed within the MFI framework [34]. This method opens the possibility to quickly encapsulate Pt particles inside zeolite frameworks in the matter of hours instead of days. In addition, Corma and coworkers encapsulated Pt particles into the sinusoidal channels of MFI zeolite by using a one-pot synthesis method with tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPA+OH−) as a template molecule [33]. It was determined that TPA+OH− occupied the intersectional voids of the MFI zeolite. This limits Pt access to the large intersectional voids [33,81,82]. As a result, most Pt clusters became entrapped in the sinusoidal channels and a small fraction of Pt was found in the straight pore channels and in the intersectional voids. Furthermore, by adding K and Sn to the synthesis mixture, Pt was further dispersed into stable PtSn subnanometric clusters (K-PtSn@MFI) inside the sinusoidal channels [35]. Another method was developed by Sun et al., incorporating subnanometric bimetallic Pt-Zn clusters into an MFI framework using ligand-protected direct H2 reduction [36]. The use of ligands was believed to stabilize the metal precursors and direct the formation of the zeolite framework around the metal species during hydrothermal synthesis [88]. H2 reduction of the ethylenediamine-protected Pt and Zn precursors, instead of a traditional calcination-reduction method, resulted in subnanometer PtZn clusters in the intersectional channels between the straight and sinusoidal 10-ring channels of the MFI structure (Fig. 2 a) [36]. It can be seen in Fig. 2b and c that PtZn clusters were confined within the MFI crystals evidenced by STEM-HAADF [36]. This method of in situ encapsulation creates Pt-zeolites that have superior stability on stream as compared to the wetness impregnation synthesized Pt-zeolites [33–36,75]. For example, K-PtSn@MFI (encapsulated Pt) was found to be robust and maintained high propane conversion (>50 %) even after 60 h on stream. [33]. In comparison, K-PtSn/MFI (incipient wetness impregnated) lost over half of its initial propane conversion (86 %) within the first 5 h on stream [33]. Furthermore, Liu et al. showed that K-PtSn@MFI was stable even under more industrially relevant condition for propane DH (50 mL/min of pure propane as feed gas, 550 °C) [35]. Under these conditions, the initial conversion of propane (20 %) was far from thermodynamic equilibrium (30 %) so to prevent the reverse reaction. The propane conversion only dropped from 20 % to 17 % after 70 h on stream [35]. Additionally, compared to a Pt-Sn/mesoporous Al2O3 catalyst (kd = 0.087 h−1), which resembles the industrially used catalyst (K-PtSn/γ-Al2O3), K-PtSn@MFI (kd = 0.012 h−1) experienced a lower rate of deactivation during the first propane DH cycle [35,89]. Other notable Zn-doped MFI-encapsulated Pt catalysts also exhibit extremely low rates of deactivation compared to Pt-Sn/mesoporous Al2O3 (kd = 0.087 h−1) [36,75]. For example, Sun et al. reported that, under optimized reaction conditions, PtZn4@S-1-H has the lowest reported deactivation rate of 0.001 h-1 [36]. Likewise, Wang et al. reported that their PtZn bimetallic nanoclusters encapsulated in MFI (0.3Pt0.5Zn@S-1, S-1 is MFI), made by hydrothermal synthesis, also experienced minimal deactivation (kd =0.002 h-1) [75]. Fig. 3 a shows that 0.3Pt0.5Zn@S-1 was robust and stable over 60 h on stream [75]. Furthermore, like Pt-Sn catalysts, 0.3Pt0.5Zn@S-1 is more stable and active compared to 0.3Pt0.5Zn/S-1 (Fig. 3b). In addition to high stability, previously mentioned zeolite-encapsulated PtSn catalysts exhibit superior recyclability [33,35,36,75]. Due to the high temperature of the regeneration step, Pt particles are prone to agglomeration which leads to loss of active sites. While the Oleflex industrial catalyst (PtSn/γ-Al2O3) has to be repeatedly regenerated by using an oxy-chloride treatment, zeolite-encapsulated Pt-Sn catalysts can be redispersed using an oxidation-reduction treatment [43]. K-PtSn@MFI catalysts can be regenerated without a significant loss of activity and without an increase in Pt particle size for three reaction cycles [33,35]. This improved recyclability could be ascribed to the enhanced interaction between the framework-encapsulated Sn and Pt where Sn particles are hypothesized to act as nucleation sites for Pt redispersion [47]. Similarly, this ability to regenerate without losing initial activity is also observed in Pt-Zn catalysts, where 0.3Pt0.5Zn@S-1 can be recycled without any obvious deactivation during three cycles (Fig. 3c) [75]. In addition to the beneficial confinement effects, zeolites contain silanol nests that can aid the alloying of rare earth metals (REMs) with Pt to create a stable and active DH catalyst [90]. REMs (e.g. La, Ce, Y) are widely used as dopants for Pt-based catalysts because they have been shown to improve Pt dispersion and reduce coking [91–93]. These advantageous qualities were attributed to improved metal-support interactions and optimized support acidity/basicity [91–93]. However, in the past, synthesizing REM-Pt alloys was a challenge because of the low reducibility of REMs [94]. Recently, Ryoo et al. developed a synthesis method to form Pt-La, Pt-Ce, and Pt-Y alloys in a degallated gallosilicate MFI framework (mz-deGa, mz = MFI) [90]. This was achieved by co-impregnating Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 and a nitrate precursor of the REMs onto degallated gallosilicate zeolites [90]. With the assistance of the silanol nests, these REM species migrated to Pt particles and then were reduced by chemisorbed hydrogen on a Pt surface creating Pt-REM alloys. While PtSn/Al2O3 and PtSn/mz lost all catalytic activity within 1 day on stream (under pure propane flow, WHSV =11 h−1), PtLa/mz-deGa remained active after 20 days on stream, with a conversion of 15 % propane and propylene selectivity over 98 % [90]. This enhanced stability was due to the electron transfer from REMs to neighboring Pt atoms that prevented coke precursors from sticking to the Pt sites [67]. This finding represents a new way to alloy Pt with REMs and it is only possible with the help of silanol nests in an MFI framework. It is possible that this method could be extended to other zeolite frameworks. Further, even though these Pt-REM materials show high catalytic activity and stability for propane DH, a compatible regeneration method still needs to be developed for these catalysts. The recent work on zeolite-encapsulated Pt catalysts discussed above have shown that using zeolites to confine Pt nanoparticles can significantly enhance the stability and recyclability [33–36,75]. Table 3 summarizes these recently developed zeolite-supported Pt materials. Despite the benefits of using zeolites as a support, current zeolite-encapsulated Pt catalyst synthesis methods are not easily scalable. From these recent Pt studies, it is apparent that the location, size of Pt active sites, and interaction between Pt and promoters depend on the fine interplay between synthesis precursors during hydrothermal treatment. Therefore, to come up with a more scalable synthesis method, it is crucial that the dynamic transformation of active sites during synthesis is understood at the atomic level. The use of advanced in situ/operando characterization techniques such as high-resolution transmission electron miscopy and integrated-differential phase contrast analysis can provide insight into the formation of Pt active site [33,35]. Once the mechanistic details of the material genesis are revealed, the next step would be to recreate the atomic environment using less complex unit operations and inexpensive chemicals. 4.2 Chromium Chromium-based materials are one of the benchmark catalysts for propane DH and are used commercially in the CATOFIN process (CB&I Lummus) and in the FBD process (Yarsintez-Snamprogetti) [11,12,97,98]. As with Pt catalysts, commercial Cr catalysts utilize Al2O3 as the support due to the robust chemical and physical properties of the material [15]. These CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts show good DH properties, with 53 mol% conversion and 86 mol% selectivity in the CATOFIN process, however there are challenges regarding catalyst stability and disposal [97,99]. In addition to the environmental challenges associated with the disposal of chromium, these catalysts suffer from rapid deactivation from coke buildup—which can be reversed by thermal regeneration—and from a gradual, but permanent, deactivation caused by repeated high temperature regenerations where Cr nanoparticles alloy with Al atoms in the support, making the active Cr site inaccessible [100]. The strong acidity of alumina supports contributes to this phenomenon [100]. 4.2.1 Non-ordered support Active CrOx-based catalysts feature a distribution of Cr(VI), Cr(V), Cr(III), and Cr(II) species on the surface, and their ratios are dependent on synthesis factors, such as loading and calcination temperatures [15]. Generally, isolated Cr(III) and Cr(II) species are considered the active sites for DH on amorphous alumina supports [101–103]. Propane adsorbs to a coordinatively unsaturated Cr(III) site where both hydrogen abstractions occur (Fig. 4 ) [100,104]. Adsorption energies for saturated-hydrocarbons and hydrogen on Cr sites are low which allows both species to leave the surface easily and not inhibit the active sites which contribute to the high catalytic activity [104]. To investigate the Al2O3 support properties that influence the Cr active sites, different Al2O3 morphologies, including γ-, δ-, and θ-, have been tested as a CrOx support [105–107]. One study found that while the ratio of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) was not influenced by the alumina structure, the catalytic rate was directly correlated to the density of Lewis acid sites (LAS) on the support [105]. γ-Al2O3 supported catalysts exhibited a lower rate and a lower density of LAS as compared to θ-Al2O3. The study concluded that LAS on Al2O3 are the anchoring sites for non-crystalline, DH active Cr(III)Ox [105]. A similar study comparing Al2O3 morphology found that higher initial rates could be observed on η-Al2O3 than on γ-Al2O3, however γ-Al2O3 remained the most stable support that limited irreversible deactivation from Cr sintering and Al-alloying [106]. Despite high activity, Al2O3-supported Cr catalysts still face drawbacks from the different forms of deactivation mentioned above, so alternative supports with different acidity, such as SiO2 and ZrO2, have been investigated to improve performance by stabilizing active sites and reducing coke formation. For example, amorphous SiO2 was found to cause Cr aggregation, which formed stable, but low-activity α-Cr2O3 [108]. This was suggested to be caused by the weak support interactions of the silica. ZrO2 catalysts have shown more promising results. The use of ZrOx both as a support and as an additive to an alumina support has resulted in catalysts with a 21 % higher propane yield (compared to a commercial analogue, K-CrOx/Al2O3) and stability over 10 DH/regeneration cycles (Fig. 5 ) [109,110]. Zr containing supports maintained highly dispersed Cr sites, even at high loadings, which prevents the formation of unselective α-Cr2O3 sites and inhibits Cr/Al alloying [110]. Higher ratios of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) were stabilized by the Zr. The Cr(VI) then reduces to the stable Cr(III) during reaction and less crystalline Cr2O3 was formed [111]. Isolated and stable Cr leads to enhanced catalyst stability and retained activity after repeated regenerations [110]. To further investigate the source of this Cr-Zr synergy, Otroshchenko et al. created two different materials for non-oxidative DH: binary CrZrOx and supported CrOx/LaZrOx [109]. The authors found that both materials were DH active. However, the binary catalyst regained full activity post-regeneration while the supported material further deactivated with each regeneration cycle due to Cr sintering [109]. Additionally, the acidic nature of the ZrO2 in the supported material and the proximity of Cr sites to one another led to increased coke formation [109]. The proposed synergistic effect of the superior binary material was from the Cr promotion of in-situ lattice oxygen removal from ZrO2, creating coordinatively unsaturated Zr sites (Zrcus), which are another propane DH active center [112]. Since ZrOx has advantageous promotional effects on Cr, researchers have further investigated this material by using other metal oxide supports. For example, Han et al. found that when adding low loadings of CrZrOx to SiO2, Al2O3, and TiO2 supports, the best propane DH activity was on the catalyst with the weakest support acidity, SiO2 [113]. CrOx interacted with SiO2 more weakly than with Al2O3 and TiO2, which facilitated a stronger interaction between the CrOx and ZrO2 species. This construction led to facile formation of active Zrcus sites. The importance of the Zr morphology in CrZrOx/SiO2 was explored in a study that found the catalytic activity increased with increasing crystallinity of ZrO2 [114]. Crystalline ZrO2 enabled more dispersed, stable Cr(III) formation on the SiO2 support than amorphous ZrO2, however, the propylene selectivity was not affected. The higher crystallinity allowed facile formation the active Zrcus sites, but it also caused more coke formation. The coke, from cracking side reactions, initially formed in small seeds then rapidly grew on the surface deactivating the catalyst. Notably, no Cr sintering was observed, and deactivation was attributed entirely to coke buildup. Therefore, the materials could be easily regenerated under thermal oxidative treatment to burn the coke and regain initial activity. 4.2.2 Ordered support A series of meso- and microporous supports have also been investigated for understanding the transformation of Cr sites and their deactivation properties. Amorphous supports showed the presence of various Cr redox sites and their deactivation through coking and sintering. More controlled synthesis is needed to better determine the support properties that increase the active site stability and prevent deactivation. Highly ordered materials like zeolites and mesoporous silica offer well-defined pore systems that can allow for better speciation control and stability under severe reaction conditions. Mesoporous Al2O3, which maintained better Cr dispersion than γ-Al2O3, is first discussed. Michorczyk and co-workers utilized mesoporous Al, which was prepared via a carbon templating synthesis method and incipient wetness impregnation [115–117]. The ratios and evolution of Cr oxidation states were observed during reaction on mesoporous alumina with different surface areas. At low loadings, Cr(VI) was the main site initially formed which underwent partial reduction at the start of reaction to form more catalytically active Cr(III) sites. Higher loadings lead to an increased quantity of Cr(V) and Cr(III) sites prior to reaction. This speciation resulted in higher activity up to a Cr loading of 20 wt%. At loadings greater than 20 wt%, Cr2O3 started obstructing the mesopores, forming an inactive phase, leading to a sharp decrease in activity. The authors claimed that the mesopores allowed for dispersion and stability of both the active Cr(III) and its precursor Cr(VI). The optimal Cr loading (22.5 wt%) on templated alumina had an initial activity of 47.4 % conversion resulting in 40.1 % and 84.7 % propylene yield and selectivity, respectively. Under regeneration conditions, the templated alumina showed better structural integrity than mesoporous silica supports. Compared to a traditional γ-Al2O3 support, the mesoporous alumina support has lower acidity and higher specific surface area allowing for better Cr dispersion and stabilization in the ordered framework [115]. Due to these factors, the catalyst could be fully regenerated after repeated cycles since the major loss of activity was not due to Cr sintering, but rather coke formation. To further investigate the speciation evolution of Cr on an ordered support with milder acidity, SBA-1 was studied. SBA-1 was potentially an ideal support due to its high surface area, low acidity, and three-dimensional pore structure that is more resistant to pore blocking [118]. SBA-1 is a cubic (Pm3n) silicate mesoporous material with 2.1–2.6 nm channels and a specific surface area of 1200-1450 m2/g [119]. Cr-containing SBA-1 with varying loadings of Cr possessed the following catalytic activity: 24.4. % conversion propane giving 88.9 % selectivity and 21.7 % yield of propylene [119]. This reaction was done under CO2-oxidative conditions. CO2 was co-fed to consume H2, via reverse water-gas shift reaction, to shift the reaction equilibrium of propane DH. The catalytic activity is attributed to the presence of Cr redox site - Cr(III), Cr(V), and Cr(VI) - of which Cr(VI) reduces to active Cr(III) [119,120]. In addition, Guo and team utilized mesoporous silica spheres with different ratios of Cr(VI) and Cr(III) [121]. The authors showed that the best catalytic activity and resistance to deactivation came from highly dispersed Cr with a Cr(VI):Cr(III) = 1.1 ratio. While, the initial performance of the catalyst was favorable, the materials undergo both reversible and irreversible deactivation, which were attributed to coke formation and the collapse of the mesoporous silica structure, respectively. Coke formation was remediated by oxidative thermal regeneration, however repeated regeneration under air has been found to result in the formation of α-Cr2O3, which is aggregated, inactive Cr that causes permanent catalyst deactivation [122]. The irreversible deactivation via the collapse of the mesoporous structure, although minimal, was attributed to loss of support textural properties from lattice oxygen consumption during DH of propane [119]. Ultimately, the catalytic activity was attributed to the presence of Cr redox site, Cr(III), Cr(V), and Cr(VI), of which Cr(VI) reduces to active Cr(III) [120]. These studies discussed above showed that Cr(III) catalyzes propane DH but will easily sinter/agglomerate to α-Cr2O3 or form this crystalline Cr at high loadings, making it inactive. Isolated Cr(VI) species, on the other hand, have been shown to reduce to active, well-dispersed Cr(III) making Cr(VI) the desired Cr configuration as an active site precursor [115,119,120]. To better determine the role of this isolated Cr redox species, Luo and coworkers successfully synthesized isolated Cr(VI) sites in mesoporous silica, MCM-41 [123]. While it has been shown previously that Cr(VI) can reduce to Cr(III) on non-ordered supports, these isolated Cr(VI) sites were stable in MCM-41 and could not easily reduce to Cr(III) which caused a significant decrease in activity. This study indicates that although Cr(VI) can serve as an important precursor to DH-active Cr, as seen in the previously discussed materials, it is not independently DH-active and its role in DH and structural evolution, in context of the surrounding species and support, must be studied further for a true understanding of the active sites. The high productivity of Cr-Zr materials for propane DH prompted further investigation to assess the synergy and the role of Cr(VI) redox species with Zr through the use of a mesoporous ZrO2 support. The mesoporous supported catalyst contained highly isolated and dispersed Cr(VI) sites at low loadings. These sites turned to oligomeric Cr(VI) species at intermediate loadings then crystalline Cr2O3 species were formed at high loadings [124]. As previously mentioned, isolated Cr(VI) does not easily reduce, resulting in a less active material, but the polymeric Cr(VI) species can readily reduce to active Cr(III). Through DFT calculations it was concluded that coordinatively unsaturated Cr(III) sites formed from the Cr(VI) oligomers are the active sites under CO2 DH conditions. Additionally, with the increased Cr loading, the strong acid sites on the ZrO2 support are covered, reducing cracking products. These materials showed high reactivity at 68 % propane conversion and 40.5 % propylene yield. Further, under CO2 co-feed there was good resistance to coke formation and activity was fully recovered after multiple regenerations. Zeolites are another high surface area ordered support that are promising for dispersing Cr, and they have tunable acidity (Si/Al ratio) which allows for additional support interaction studies. For example, a series of β-type framework zeolites (Si/Al = 17, 1000) were impregnated with Cr using a wet impregnation method [125]. β-zeolites have a three-dimensional pore structure with intersecting channels that form 12-membered rings with a 0.67 nm diameter [126]. The dealuminated form exhibited the best catalytic activity at 7 wt% Cr with 33.3 % propane conversion resulting in 27.2 % yield and 81.6 % selectivity of propylene respectively under CO2 DH conditions. This was attributed to the absence of strong Al acid sites in the dealuminated materials which led to fewer cracking products, as compared to the Al containing zeolites. Similar to the mesoporous supports, Cr(VI) was identified as active precursor that rapidly reduces to Cr(III) species. With increasing Cr content, the propylene yield also increased proportionally until a loading of 5 wt% [125]. A more thorough analysis of the effect of acid sites on a highly ordered aluminosilicate support was carried out by Yuan and co-workers [127]. Here, Cr supported on high on ZSM-5 with various Si/Al ratios was used to investigate the role of support acid sites in propane DH. Cr-ZSM-5 with Si/Al = 260 gave the highest propylene yield of 45.2 % which was maintained after 5 h TOS. Similar to previous reports, catalytic activity increased with Cr loading up to 7 wt%, after which there was a decrease in rate and evidence of crystalline Cr2O3 particles. The high Si/Al catalyst also showed strong resistance to coke formation with only 0.6 wt% coke as compared to 5.6 wt% on a traditional alumina supported version. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments indicated that Brønsted acid sites strongly adsorbed propane, which led to higher selectivity towards cracking products. While high concentration of Brønsted acidity is detrimental towards selectivity, Brønsted acidity was found to be beneficial to the DH mechanism by providing propane adsorption sites. This was shown using C3H8/C3H6-TPD experiments in high Si/Al zeolites which displayed the best catalytic activity [127]. In summary, both zeolites and mesoporous supports were beneficial for controlling the Cr speciation to gain insight into the Cr catalyzed propane DH, and these highly ordered frameworks they have potential for future application. The initial catalytic activity was similar across both classes of materials, and Cr speciation is similar at low loadings, but zeolites allowed for higher dispersion at increased loadings which prevented crystalline Cr2O3 formation and long-term deactivation. Despite these advantages, zeolites and other highly structured materials can potentially degrade under repeated high regeneration temperatures, making them unsuitable for long-term industrial application. However, there is still room to investigate Cr-catalyzed DH, especially in support effects for activation/regeneration and dopant synergy. Several promoters such as Zr, and Sn have been successfully used to improve the performance of Cr catalysts [109,110,128]. Precision synthesis with dopants can provide insight into the structural characteristics needed for more directed catalysts design. Nonetheless, the complex and costly synthesis, as well as the structural integrity of an ordered support as compared to traditional amorphous supports might be a significant hurdle for large-scale industrial application. 5 Oxidative dehydrogenation Propane ODH is an alternative and attractive method for making propylene due to its lower energetic and thermodynamic characteristics [129]. ODH proceeds by a parallel-consecutive scheme (Scheme 1 ): (i) the propane ODH to propylene; (ii) the direct combustion of propane to COx; and (iii) the overoxidation of propylene to COx [10,17]. As seen in Fig. 6 b, V/SiO2 leads, at high conversion, to the overoxidation of the desired olefin product [130]. Because of this, a selective and active ODH catalyst still remains elusive. To date, the most promising candidates are vanadium oxide and boron-based catalysts. Vanadium oxide is, by far, the most studied catalyst for propane ODH, although little progress has been made to improve this catalyst in the past 20 years. The use of porous materials to support VOx has brought about more active catalysts, which will be discussed below. In addition to VOx catalysts, boron-containing materials were recently discovered as a highly active and selective catalyst for propane ODH. The use of porous materials helps elucidate the mechanism of these new boron-containing materials. 5.1 Vanadium oxide Vanadium oxide is prevalent in industry as a catalyst for sulfuric acid synthesis and ethanol oxidation [17,131]. This is because V2O5 is environmentally friendly and has high redox capabilities [10,17]. Due to its high redox activity, VOx is one of the most studied catalysts for propane ODH [10,17]. It has been determined that the degree of VOx dispersion is a major component that dictates the catalytic performance. This is because the degree of VOx dispersion on a support affects the structure of VOx active site, which dictates the selectivity of the catalyst [10]. When VOx is dispersed on a support, there are three possible structures: monomeric VOx, polymeric VOx, and V2O5 nanoparticles [10]. When the loading of V is below the anchoring capability of the support (monolayer limit), monomeric and polymeric VOx are formed (Fig. 6a). However, when V loading exceeds the monolayer limit, V2O5 nanoparticles become prevalent (Fig. 6a). It is generally accepted in the literature that dispersed VOx sites are the most selective to propylene, while V2O5 is known to accelerate combustion (Fig. 6b) [10]. Therefore, to achieve high propylene selectivity, it is generally believed that the VOx active sites must be well dispersed to prevent overoxidation. It is believed that the dispersion can affect the selectivity of the active sites but not the TOF (mole of propane/mole of surface VOx). For VOx catalysts, it is widely accepted that the material accelerates the ODH reaction, which proceeds by the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [10,17]. According to the MvK mechanism, propane undergoes dehydrogenation by a surface oxygen species of VOx to yield propylene. The reduced VOx species is then re-oxidized by gas-phase oxygen. There are conflicting reports as to what constitutes the active surface oxygen species, but it is suggested to be either an oxygen in a V = O or V-O-S species (Fig. 7 ) [131,132]. For example, DFT calculations showed that the first H-abstraction from propane happens on the V = O of the O = V(O–S)3 site while the second H-abstraction from the propyl radical could occur on either V = O or V-O-S (Fig. 7) [132]. On highly dispersed VOx catalysts with only isolated O = V(O–S)3 sites, the second C–H abstraction most likely occurred over another O = V(O–S)3 site instead of over the formed HO-V(IV)O3 site because of the fast rate of reoxidation (Fig. 7) [132]. Nevertheless, both experimental data and DFT calculation agree that, below monolayer coverage of VOx, the TOF of propane ODH is not influenced by the dispersion of active sites [10,132]. 5.1.1 Nonordered support Even though it is difficult to improve the TOF of a VOx site on a support by simply dispersing VOx, anchoring more active VOx sites does improve the propylene productivity [133,134]. Because of this, significant efforts have been made to find a support that enables a high loading of isolated vanadium oxide. One such support that has been of interest is amorphous SiO2 because its low acidity inhibits unwanted reactions [29]. However, SiO2 is known to anchor 3-times less V per surface area (monolayer ≈ 3.3 V/nm2) compared to more active supports, such as TiO2 and Al2O3 (monolayer ≈ 9 V/nm2). This was attributed to the low −OH surface-concentration (∼4.6 −OH/nm2) of SiO2 [135]. As a result, several methods have been developed to increase the dispersion of VOx on the SiO2 surface. For example, Grant et al. found that adding a small amount of Na (0.4 % weight) to SiO2 increased the monolayer limit from 3.3 V/nm2 to 9 V/nm2, which led to an increase in propylene yield [134]. Recent research on VOx supported on nonordered materials mostly focuses on understanding the formation of active sites using DFT, grafting, and SOMC techniques [136,137]. Insight into the making of active sites on these nonordered supports can enable better use of surface anchoring groups to disperse more VOx and enable the design of more productive catalyst. 5.1.2 Ordered support Porous Si-based materials with high surface area have been explored for increasing the dispersion of VOx as these supports can isolate VOx. Julbe et al. prepared a V-MFI framework catalyst by direct synthesis that contained highly dispersed V4+ species [138]. The vanadium speciation in V-MFI was determined by EPR and showed that the vanadium was well-dispersed (V4+) within the MFI-framework rather than agglomerated (V5+), which would be EPR inactive due to the lack of unpaired electrons [139,140]. Further, it was found that the synthesis technique can impact the dispersion and performance of vanadium catalysts supported on porous Si-based materials [141–144]. Búlanek et al. found that V supported on hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) made by direct synthesis (s-S) had improved V dispersion and reaction performance as compared to the V-impregnated HMS (i-S) (Fig. 8 ) [133]. At high loading of V (>5% weight loading), i-S samples show XRD peaks of V2O5 nanoparticles (Fig. 8a). In contrast, VOx was well dispersed on s-S samples (Fig. 8b). The higher amount of dispersed VOx led to higher propylene productivity in s-S samples compared to i-S samples (Fig. 8c). Improved propylene yield has also been reported for directly synthesized vanadosilicates [141–144]. Even though there are reports of the same or lower propylene yields in vanadosilicate catalysts formed by direct synthesis, it is important to note that these materials do not contain an increased loading of vanadium active sites compared to VOx supported on amorphous materials [145,146]. Along with manipulating dispersion, efforts have been made to further improve propylene yield by using ordered supports as it is hypothesized that the mesopores of ordered structures can accelerate propylene desorption and increase propylene selectivity [147–151]. However, there are contradictory claims about the effect of mesopores on propylene selectivity. Fan and coworkers found that V/SBA-15 was more active and selective in propane ODH compared to V/SiO2 [147]. They suggested that the mesopores of SBA-15 can accelerate propylene desorption and, therefore, increases propylene selectivity [147,148]. However, it is not possible to directly compare selectivity between the different V catalysts in these papers because these materials had different V loadings and the catalytic data was not collected at iso-conversion. In contrast, two other research groups meticulously investigated the effect of the support porosity and observed that the size of pores had negligible effect on propylene selectivity [149,148–151]. The catalytic data from these groups exhibited the same propane conversion at the same V loading, allowing for the direct comparison of the various porous supports on propylene selectivity. Furthermore, the reaction pathways of propane ODH and combustion are interwoven due to the participation of lattice oxygen in both reactions (i.e., VOx species are responsible for both propane activation and propylene combustion) [10]. Therefore, it is difficult to tailor the selectivity to propylene by just simply dispersing V active sites on porous supports. In addition, Bulánek et al. found that the effect of different ordered frameworks on propylene selectivity at 13 % isoconversion of propane is unnoticeable (Fig. 9 ). Multiple other factors, such as surface acidity, basicity, and redox ability can contribute to the C–H activation and CC cleavage steps that lead to COx. Therefore, it is important to carefully examine the reaction conditions and catalyst properties to explain the changes in product selectivity when multiple factors can alter reaction pathways. Overall, ordered supports can potentially be used to increase VOx dispersion and propylene space-time yield. The direct synthesis of porous material-supported VOx has been shown as an effective way to produce high density VOx materials and lead to a more productive catalyst for ODH [133,141–144]. However, the increase in propylene yield from directly synthesized materials is caused primarily by a boost in V loading, resulting in a larger concentration of active sites. This results in a greater quantity of propane converted, but not an increase in propylene selectivity. Therefore, it is necessary to improve the synthesis methods such that the resulting material has enhanced selectivity towards propylene to make this reaction industrially viable. Oxidative dehydrogenation-chemical looping technology (ODH-CL) has been used as a promising method in increasing propylene selectivity [152,153]. Although the idea of chemical looping can be dated back to the 1940’s, its use for propane ODH has not been fully realized and more research is needed [154]. What makes ODH-CL unique is that the dehydrogenation and oxidation processes are decoupled. First, propane is dehydrogenated by lattice oxygen on a supported VOx material in the dehydrogenation reactor (the reducer). Next, the reduced catalyst is re-oxidized in air in the regenerator. By separating propane dehydrogenation from surface reoxidation, the over-oxidation of propylene by gas phase oxygen is limited [152]. Chen et al. used chemical looping oxidative dehydrogenation to examine the effect of V loading on catalytic performance of V/TiO2 catalysts. A significantly higher propylene selectivity (80 % at 20 % propane conversion) was achieved on 4 V/TiO2 using CL-ODH, as compared to the 19.9 % propylene selectivity of a 2.5 V/TiO2 run in conventional tube at 21.2 % propane conversion [153,155]. Additionally, the heat of the re-oxidation reactor is used to supply heat for the endothermic dehydrogenation reactor, which brings down the energy cost [156]. Adding a second metal oxide (promoter) such as Mo, Nb, Ta to supported VOx catalyst can modify the coordination environment, reducibility, and dispersion of V centers [157–159]. Understanding the interaction between promoter and VOx can provide insight for better catalyst design. However, catalyst optimization (composition of each metal oxide) can be quite challenging since the synergy between metal oxide and VOx is not simply proportional to the loading of each metal [157,160]. 5.2 Boron oxide In contrast to the long-studied V-based ODH catalysts, boron-containing materials have only newly been investigated as highly productive catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane [161–164]. Most recently, computational and precision synthesis efforts have been made to understand the mechanism and active-site structure behind these highly selective boron-based materials [165–169]. One primary advantage boron has over the current state-of-the-art vanadium-based catalysts is high olefin selectivity and fewer combustion products. While V-based catalysts have COx as their major byproduct, boron catalysts produce ethylene as the most abundant byproduct, indicating that this material operates via a different mechanism than the extensively studied V catalysts. Therefore, the recent advances in the boron have focused on both the active component structure and the mechanism. 5.2.1 Non-ordered support Of the boron-containing non-porous materials that have been investigated for ODHP, hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) and metal-oxide-supported boron are the most pertinent. Hexagonal boron nitride is a 2D honeycomb layered material that is isostructural to graphene [170]. In 2016, the Hermans group showed that h-BN had a high selectivity to propylene (79 % at 11 % conversion), and the primary by-product was ethylene (12 % selectivity), which is another high value olefin (Fig. 10 ) [161]. Initial computational studies with h-BN suggested that B-edge sites were responsible for the activity [162,163,171]. Later studies found that the high selectivity was not specific to the h-BN material, but to boron itself. Hermans et al. demonstrated that other boron-containing catalysts, including B4C, Ti2B, NiB, Co2B, HfB2, and WB had high propylene selectivity (Fig. 10) [172]. Across all these active materials, an oxy-functionalized surface made up of an amorphous oxyhydroxide BOx layer over the bulk material was observed which was proposed to contain the active species for these catalysts [172]. Use of magic angle spinning solid-state NMR (MAS SS-NMR) and soft x-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) on h-BN and BNNT showed that the pristine boron surface prior reaction formed a layer of trigonal boron oxide with various hydroxyl and bridging oxide groups after treatment under ODH conditions [173]. The observation of this B(OH)xO3-x surface opposed the theory that h-BN edge sites are the active species, and currently the active site’s identity is still up for debate. To further investigate the speciation and source of high propane ODH activity, boron was dispersed on supported amorphous silica with the intent of isolating active boron sites [174,175]. In these studies, synthesis via incipient wetness impregnation resulted in a variety of isolated and aggregated trigonal boron sites (Fig. 11 ) including planar boroxyl rings and polymerized boron with hydroxyl and framework Si terminated oxygen bonds. Hermans and co-workers identified the pre- and post-reaction boron species and found the boron surface restructured to contain more hydroxylated moieties with increased BB connectivity. They indicated that the aggregated, oxidized boron species (described as B2(OH)xO(3-x/2) where x<6) are formed in-situ and are responsible for catalytic activity [174]. In a parallel study using silica supported boron, the Lu group claimed that boroxyl rings and tricoordinate planar BO3/2 species are the active species for ODHP. Their materials were productive (84.1 % propylene selectivity at 2.8 % propane conversion) at temperatures as low as 405 °C [175]. While there is debate about the ODHP active site, both studies showed that the supported materials had lower selectivity than h-BN due partially to higher ethylene selectivity (76.9 % propylene selectivity at 5% propane conversion), but the product distribution was similar, with ethylene constituting the main byproduct [174]. Additionally, the post reaction surface compositions were similar to that of h-BN post-reaction indicating a common, mobile BOx surface species between materials [176]. While these synthetic studies provided insights into the transformation of the active catalyst surface, more controlled synthesis will provide further active site information. In addition to silica, Al2O3 has been studied as a boron support to better understand the boron active site. From these studies, a BOx surface was also identified [177]. Here, it was determined that both BO3 and BO4 species were present in the active catalyst (45 % propylene selectivity at 25 % propane conversion), but the BO4 species were inactive for ODH. Further, boria-based catalysts on Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, and MgO supports have also tested and investigated by 11B-NMR [178]. The TiO2 and ZrO2 supports had the good selectivity to propylene at 74 % and 68 % respectively, and the alumina support, while less selective, has higher conversion and a propylene yield of 22 %. SS-NMR investigation of the alumina support revealed that crystalline B2O3 was not active. Samples with more BO3 than BO4 species had higher catalytic activity indicating that BO3 species were likely the active species. Under ODH conditions these materials were found to severely deactivate due to the formation of a B-Al phase prone to overoxidation of the alkane. More recently, Loiland et al. showed that doping h-BN with MgO increases the conversion (for a propane/ethane mixed alkane feed) up to 10-fold as compared to native h-BN with a drop in C2−3 selectivity from 94 % to79 % [179]. The promotional effect is explained by MgO being a low valence dopant that decreases the energy needed to create an oxygen vacancy on the surface. MgO is also credited with more easily desorbing olefins. In addition to structure-based catalytic studies, several mechanistic and computational based studies have been recently done on this system, which identify a mixed surface and gas phase reaction pathway [165,166]. These topics are not the focus of this work and will not be discussed in detail. Additional boron ODH studies with other alkanes as well as more in-depth reviews have been published [180,181]. 5.2.2 Ordered support To further investigate the proposed active phase described as B2(OH)xO(3-x/2) where x<6, controlled synthesis of boron sites has been achieved inside zeolite frameworks. Incorporation of boron was done both hydrothermally and post synthetically via IWI [167,168]. As a follow up to their boron on silica publication, Hermans and co-workers, created isolated BO3 sites in the aluminum-free form of zeolite MCM-22 (B-MWW) through hydrothermal synthesis [167]. Stable and isolated BO3-type sites were formed within the zeolite framework (Fig. 12 ) and surprisingly exhibited no significant propylene conversion. A narrow distribution of boron oxide species was identified in the T-sites of the zeolite which were terminated by framework O-Si and hydroxyl OH bonds, BO3 and BOH. The B-MWW was inactive for ODH, but the same sample when post-synthetically treated with addition of boron using IWI showed comparable catalytic activity to B/SiO2. The additional boron formed external surface species similar to the polymerized boron seen on B/SiO2 materials. Although B-MWW material is compositionally analogous to the active B/SiO2 materials previously reported in the literature, the boron speciation did not contain boroxyl rings or oligomerized boron, as evidenced by high-field NMR. This lack of activity over stable, accessible BO3 sites indicated that ODH activity over boron-based catalysts is not due to a single boron oxide site. Instead, active materials are likely characterized by two major factors: the boron site mobility, and BOB connectivity [169]. In addition, the Lu group synthesized a layered MWW type zeolite incorporated with boron [168]. This material was active for propane ODH with 83.6 % propylene selectivity at 3.9 % propane conversion at 500 °C. These materials behaved similarly to B/SiO2 materials previously reported possibly due to having a similar distribution of trigonal boron species [174]. Among the variety of three- and four- coordinate boron identified via solid-state 11B-NMR, two different three-coordinate boron sites were suggested as the active species. The structure of the active boron is described as a zeolite defect site bonded to a hydroxyl group, the Si framework, and potentially a boron or Si framework site. Solid-state 11B-NMR indicated that the boron atoms restructured during a 20 h TOS under propane ODH conditions. The current comparison of both amorphous and ordered silica supported catalyst point to the importance of boron surface mobility and long-range coordination with other boron atoms. There is still limited literature on using ordered porous supports for boron catalyzed ODH, and more investigation is needed to fully understand the active site generation and its role in the mixed surface, gas phase reaction pathway. 6 Summary and outlook The development of new ordered materials has brought about exciting research opportunities in the area of propane DH and ODH. This review summarizes how structured materials can be used to study reaction mechanisms while also improving catalytic performance. Through designing the synthesis process, it is possible to meticulously tailor the nature of the active sites to increase the efficiency of DH and ODH catalysts. However, due to the complicated fabrication process of ordered materials, the use of expensive precursors, and, possibly, the tedious synthesis, it is important to consider the following points when using ordered material as a support for DH and ODH: 1 Pt-catalyzed DH. The complicated fabrication process makes these materials rather inaccessible and difficult to scale up despite that the new structured materials, which imbed Pt in their matrixes, have shown to be more robust compared to industrially applied PtSn/γ-Al2O3 (with 1% K) catalyst for DH. The increased interaction between Pt and dopants (Sn, Zn) within zeolite channels leads to more coke-resistant and regenerative propane DH catalysts. Therefore, it is important to use in situ/operando characterization techniques to understand the formation of the active sites. By using this obtained insight about the material genesis at a molecular level, a more accessible synthesis process could be developed. 2 Cr-catalyzed DH. Application of ordered zeolite and mesoporous supports led to more insight into the role and evolution of Cr redox sites due to the support’s ability to isolate and stabilize the structure of interest. Crystalline supports can potentially be applied for the investigation and refinement of dopant-effects that have been observed on non-ordered supports. In contrast, commercially used Cr materials have a short catalyst life, due to fast deactivation from coke formation and gradual deactivation form coverage of active sites. The use of non-ordered supports allows for accessible synthesis and investigation of dopant synergy. 3 Vanadium oxide-catalyzed ODH. To further improve supported VOx system, it is crucial that we separately investigate the role of other factors such as acidity, basicity, and electronic effects individually. The use of ordered support can increase the amount of V loading in propane ODH while maintaining the selectivity and, therefore, improve the propylene productivity. However, factors that affect propylene selectivity are still under debate. The use of in-situ spectroscopy could aid this process and guide a more directed design of catalyst. Techniques such as Shell-Isolated Nanoparticle-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SHINERS) could be used to increase the sensitivity of commonly used Raman spectroscopy to get more insight into the mechanism of propane ODH [182]. Additionally, it is also possible to improve the performance of V catalysts through the use of chemical looping technology, which decouples the dehydrogenation and oxidation reactions. 4 Novel materials. Beside intensively studied Pt in DH and V in ODH, other potential and cheap candidates that can be used for these reactions are C, B, Ni and Co. Materials made of these elements have been shown to have considerable activity in DH/ODH. Research into the working mechanism these materials could potentially lead to discovery of a new catalyst that can substitute the industrially applied Pt and CrOx materials that are prone to deactivation. 5 Platform to study catalyst mechanism. Not only can ordered supports improve catalytic performance in some systems, but it is also an excellent platform to study mechanism as the coordination of the active site can be carefully controlled. Zeolites have provided a means to study the formation of active sites of B in ODH. Since MWW-isolated and well-defined BOx was inactive in ODH, it was suggested that the active sites of BOx catalysts possess complicated structure. 6 Cofeeding other gases. Methods such as cofeeding CO2, other mild oxidants in ODH or H2 in DH can reduce issues such as overoxidation and sintering [183,184]. However, careful consideration regarding safety concerns is critical to make these reaction modifications possible at large scale. Adding H2 to the reaction mixture could increase the chance of explosion as the lower flammability limit of H2 is sensitive to pressure changes [185]. coredata.dc:description: Propylene is an important chemical feedstock that is largely produced via cracking of oil-derived naphtha. Direct conversion of propane into propylene may be a more attractive alternative. Specifically, propane dehydrogenation (DH) and oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) are promising for this transformation, albeit only DH has been industrially implemented. However, even the best DH catalysts (Pt-based) still suffer from deactivation. VOx- and BOx-based ODH catalysts result in significant over-oxidation and lack a mechanistic understanding. A common challenge in developing these catalysts is the broad distribution of surface species caused by the use of non-ordered catalyst supports. This hampers clear structure-performance correlations. Recent progress in the preparation of well-defined active sites on ordered supports has brought about improved catalysts, as well as fundamental insight into the working mechanism. This review will highlight recent advancements in the development of these catalysts and provide direction on the use of ordered supports for propane upgrading.
coredata.dc:title: Assessment and comparison of ordered & non-ordered supported metal oxide catalysts for upgrading propane to propylene
